Comment: From Noah Rosenblum, Associate Professor of Law at New York University School:  When we think about the United States government, the Constitution actually doesn’t say very much about what that government is supposed to look like. But over the course of the last two centuries, different problems have arisen at the federal level, and in response to each of those problems, Congress has had to create different kinds of institutions, or agencies. If we think of the sum of all those agencies together, that’s what makes the administrative state. Most of these agencies have been created by statute and follow a similar process: A problem presents itself, and Congress passes a law.  But when it comes to DOGE, the Trump administration did not follow this process.
